---
title: Brown-Sequard Syndrome
---

Brown-Sequard syndrome is a clinical syndrome of SCI involving a hemisection

# Types

:::{layout-ncol="2"}

### Brown-Sequard Syndrome

- Complete hemisection
- True hemisections are rare


### Brown-Sequard Plus Syndrome

- Partial hemisection
- More common @osullivanPhysicalRehabilitation2019
:::

# Etiology


- Typically caused by penetration woundsâ€”that is, gunshot or stab [@osullivanPhysicalRehabilitation2019; @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022]
- Herniated cervical disc @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Post-traumatic arachnoiditis @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Chiropractic manipulation @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Tumor (primary or metastatic) @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Multiple sclerosis @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Other inflammatory/infectious causes @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Spinal cord ischemia / spinal epidural hematoma @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Spinal subdural hematoma @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Hematomyelia @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 
- Spinal cord herniation @brazisLocalizationClinicalNeurology2022 




# Sensory Function

:::{layout-ncol="2"}

## Ipsilateral

- Paralysis & Sensory Loss
- DCML
    - Proprioception
    - Light touch
    - Vibratory sense
- [LCST]({{< var ref-lateral-corticospinal-tract.path >}})
    - Paralysis

## Contralateral

- Spinothalamic tract
    - Pain
    - Temperature
    - note: these symptoms will begin several dermatome segments below the level of injury @osullivanImprovingFunctionalOutcomes2016

:::


# Prognosis

- Good functional gains are typically achieved during inpatient rehab @osullivanPhysicalRehabilitation2019.
